<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two new coordination polymers {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BTC)(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] <ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (BTC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate) and {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NA)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (NA<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nicotinate) had been synthesized under the hydrothermal condition and characterized by elemental analyses, IR, and the single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a new three-dimensional network composed by tetranuclear Co cluster. It can be seen constructed by two-dimensional Co–O inorganic layers supported by BTC ligands. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is also a three-dimensional network. To our surprise, Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both contain honeycomb-like structure surrounded by Co clusters and BTC, NA ligands. We think it is difficult to construct such structures with asymmetry ligand such as BTC and NA. Furthermore, the thermal stability properties of the two complexes are studied.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new coordination polymers {[Co2(BTC)(OH)(H2O)2] 2 ⋅2H2O}n (1) (BTC=1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate) and {Co2(NA)4(H2O)}n (2) (NA=nicotinate) had been synthesized under the hydrothermal condition and characterized by elemental analyses, IR, and the single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complexes 1 is a new three-dimensional network composed by tetranuclear Co cluster. It can be seen constructed by two-dimensional Co-O inorganic layers supported by BTC ligands. Complex 2 is also a three-dimensional network. To our surprise, Complex 1 and 2 both contain honeycomb-like structure surrounded by Co clusters and BTC, NA ligands. We think it is difficult to construct such structures with asymmetry ligand such as BTC and NA. Furthermore, the thermal stability properties of the two complexes are studied.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The construction of novel metal-organic frameworks is of considerable interest and important in recent years, owing to not only their intriguing structural motifs but also their potential applications in catalysis, medicine, host–guest chemistry and the promising photo-, electro-, and magnetic materials . In general, structural motifs of these metal-organic frameworks are closely related to the geometry around the metal centers and the number of coordination sits provided by the organic ligands . So, the combination of a metal “node” and a ligand “spacer” is important for the construction of novel metal-organic frameworks . During the past decades, many high-dimensional coordination complexes have been desinged and synthesized through symmetrical organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands owing to their high symmetry and structural predicablility, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate . Despite the rich coordination chemistry exhibited by high symmetry ligands, studies on low symmetrical ligands are less reported comparatively . We think this may be because of the asymmetry of the ligand bringing much difficulty experimentally in crystallization. However, through carefully controlling the reactions, we found these kinds of ligands are versatile organic connectors for the construction of metal-organic framework . Based on the aforementioned points, the aim of our research is to synthesize novel high-dimensional coordination polymers through combining the merits of asymmetry of benzene carboxylate and 3d metals.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of novel metal-organic frameworks is of considerable interest and important in recent years, owing to not only their intriguing structural motifs but also their potential applications in catalysis, medicine, host-guest chemistry and the promising photo-, electro-, and magnetic materials . In general, structural motifs of these metal-organic frameworks are closely related to the geometry around the metal centers and the number of coordination sits provided by the organic ligands . So, the combination of a metal "node" and a ligand "spacer" is important for the construction of novel metal-organic frameworks . During the past decades, many high-dimensional coordination complexes have been desinged and synthesized through symmetrical organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands owing to their high symmetry and structural predicablility, such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate . Despite the rich coordination chemistry exhibited by high symmetry ligands, studies on low symmetrical ligands are less reported comparatively . We think this may be because of the asymmetry of the ligand bringing much difficulty experimentally in crystallization. However, through carefully controlling the reactions, we found these kinds of ligands are versatile organic connectors for the construction of metal-organic framework . Based on the aforementioned points, the aim of our research is to synthesize novel high-dimensional coordination polymers through combining the merits of asymmetry of benzene carboxylate and 3d metals.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Having studied plenty of literature, we find 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate and nicotinate are good candidates for assembly of high-dimensional metal-organic architectures for several reasons: They can be partially or fully protonated to generate different anions at various pH values, and this results in some interesting structures, through the coordination interaction and hydrogen bonds . The fully deprotonated anions are planar and have well-defined metal binding sites and have been used as linear spacer ligand . The asymmetry makes them are act as a prechiral or noncentrosymmetric ligand to provide an effective way to the construction of some acentric materials. They are all good candidates for developing molecular building blocks that may yield a new generation of metal-organic frameworks with different topologies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Having studied plenty of literature, we find 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate and nicotinate are good candidates for assembly of high-dimensional metal-organic architectures for several reasons: They can be partially or fully protonated to generate different anions at various pH values, and this results in some interesting structures, through the coordination interaction and hydrogen bonds . The fully deprotonated anions are planar and have well-defined metal binding sites and have been used as linear spacer ligand . The asymmetry makes them are act as a prechiral or noncentrosymmetric ligand to provide an effective way to the construction of some acentric materials. They are all good candidates for developing molecular building blocks that may yield a new generation of metal-organic frameworks with different topologies.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">It is well known that Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations are able to coordinate simultaneously in solution to both oxygen atoms and nitrogen atoms. Furthermore, compared with other divalent transition metals, Co(II) has the less likely probability of variations in its coordination geometry. In this article, we adopted BTC and NA and synthesized two coordination polymers: {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BTC)(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NA)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Furthermore, the thermal stability properties of the two coordination polymers are studied.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is well known that Co2+ cations are able to coordinate simultaneously in solution to both oxygen atoms and nitrogen atoms. Furthermore, compared with other divalent transition metals, Co(II) has the less likely probability of variations in its coordination geometry. In this article, we adopted BTC and NA and synthesized two coordination polymers: {[Co2(BTC)(OH)(H2O)2]2 ⋅2H2O} n  (1) and {Co2(NA)4(H2O)} n  (2). Furthermore, the thermal stability properties of the two coordination polymers are studied.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

General methods and materials

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, N, H,) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. The content of Co was determined by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. FT/IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000-400cm-1 on an Alpha Centaut FTIR spectrophotometer using a KBr pellet. TG analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1.

Syntheses

{Co2(NA)4(H2O)}n (2)

The best crystals of complex 2 were prepared from a reaction mixture of Co (OAc)2 ⋅2H2O (0.10g), NA (0.12g 0.50 mmol) and 6ml H2O, stirred for 30min, and then the pH value was adjusted to 6 with 1M NaOH. After stirring for another 30min, the mixture was transferred to a 23ml Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb and kept at 160°C under autogenous pressure for 4 days. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 24h. A large amount of red block crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 54% (base on Co). Anal. Calcd. for complex 2: C, 46.13% H, 2.96% N, 8.89% Co, 17.75%. Found: C, 46.30% H, 2.81% N, 8.62% Co, 17.79%. IR: 3315(m), 1616(w), 1591(s), 1543(s), 1476(w), 1447(w), 1411(s), 1311(w), 1284(w), 1159(w), 1113(w), 1006(w), 1000(w), 989(w), 957(w), 858(w), 843(w), 755(m), 712(m), 680(w), 607(w), 541 (w).

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single crystals of complex 1-2 were glued on glass fibers. Data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer at 293K using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) and IP technique. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 using the SHELXTL 97 crystallographic software package . Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps. Further details of the X-ray structural analysis are given in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in   . Crystal data and structure refinement, atomic coordinate, bond lengths and angles, and anisotropic displacement parameters are available in supplementary crystallographic data ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Structure description</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The single crystal structural analysis shows that the structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a unique three-dimensional framework. The fundamental unit is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a. There are two crystallographic independent Co centers in the asymmetric unit that are linked by BTC ligands, which exhibit different coordination environments. The first Co ion is coordinated by six oxygen atoms, four of which come from four different BTC ligands, with the Co–O distance range from 1.992 to 2.225<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, one water molecule and one hydroxide group with the Co–O distance 2.114 and 2.063<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. This results in distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The other Co center is coordinated by three oxygen atoms (O4, O7, O9) from three BTC ligands with the distance from 2.092 to 2.265<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. One water molecule, and two hydroxide groups occupied the other coordination sites to complete a distorted octahedral coordination environment.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure description

The single crystal structural analysis shows that the structure of complex 1 is a unique three-dimensional framework. The fundamental unit is shown in  a. There are two crystallographic independent Co centers in the asymmetric unit that are linked by BTC ligands, which exhibit different coordination environments. The first Co ion is coordinated by six oxygen atoms, four of which come from four different BTC ligands, with the Co-O distance range from 1.992 to 2.225Å, one water molecule and one hydroxide group with the Co-O distance 2.114 and 2.063Å, respectively. This results in distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The other Co center is coordinated by three oxygen atoms (O4, O7, O9) from three BTC ligands with the distance from 2.092 to 2.265Å. One water molecule, and two hydroxide groups occupied the other coordination sites to complete a distorted octahedral coordination environment.

As can be seen, BTC, being a multi-carboxylate ligand, can exhibit versatile binding modes in the construction of polymeric complexes; it acts as a seven-connector in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, this coordination mode had never been found in BTC acid.</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The assembly of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be considered constructing through two steps: the first is the construction of the two-dimensional layer and the second is the extension of the two-dimensional layer. Two {CoO6} octahedral are first connected together via position-2 carboxyl groups from BTC ligand to form a binuclear Co cluster and then two neighboring binuclear Co clusters are further connected by two hydroxide groups to generate a tetranuclear nuclear cluster. The adjacent tetranuclear Co clusters are linked via position-1 carboxyl groups and one oxygen atom (O3) from position-2 carboxyl groups in the chelating mode along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis to form a one-dimensional chain. At the same time, the other oxygen atom (O7) from position-2 carboxyl group linked the adjacent chains to generate two-dimensional layers (as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a). The two adjacent two-dimensional layers are connected by BTC ligand with different carboxylate groups to form a three-dimensional pillar-layer structure (as shown in b). The most interesting thing is such a connection mode results in a hexagon “cavity” surrounded by BTC ligand with the water molecular in it along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis (as shown in a).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The assembly of complex 1 can be considered constructing through two steps: the first is the construction of the two-dimensional layer and the second is the extension of the two-dimensional layer. Two {CoO6} octahedral are first connected together via position-2 carboxyl groups from BTC ligand to form a binuclear Co cluster and then two neighboring binuclear Co clusters are further connected by two hydroxide groups to generate a tetranuclear nuclear cluster. The adjacent tetranuclear Co clusters are linked via position-1 carboxyl groups and one oxygen atom (O3) from position-2 carboxyl groups in the chelating mode along b-axis to form a one-dimensional chain. At the same time, the other oxygen atom (O7) from position-2 carboxyl group linked the adjacent chains to generate two-dimensional layers (as shown in  a). The two adjacent two-dimensional layers are connected by BTC ligand with different carboxylate groups to form a three-dimensional pillar-layer structure (as shown in b). The most interesting thing is such a connection mode results in a hexagon "cavity" surrounded by BTC ligand with the water molecular in it along the b-axis (as shown in a).

<ce:para view="all">The single crystallographic analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also exhibits an interesting three-dimensional network. The fundamental unit is shown in b. There are two crystallographically unique Co centers in the asymmetric unit. The NA ligand adopts two kinds of coordination modes as shown in b. The Co(1) center is defined by two nitrogen atoms of two NA ligands with distance Co(1)–N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.154<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å Co(2)–N(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.129<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, two oxygen atoms (Co(1)–O(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Co(1)–O(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.035<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) from two bridging carboxylate groups of another two NA ligands, one oxygen atom (Co(1)–O(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.076<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) from a monodentate carboxylate group. Another coordination site is occupied by a water molecular with Co(1)–O(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The O–Co(2)–O bond angles are in the range of 83.96°–175.66°. The Co (2) center also adopts distorted octahedral coordination mode, and connected with three oxygen atoms from three carboxylate groups of the NA ligands, two of them with bridging coordination mode, and another adopts monodentate coordination mode with O–Co (2)–O bond angle in the range of 83.79°–178.01° and bond distance range from 2.044 to 2.155<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, one oxygen atom from water molecular, and two nitrogen atoms form NA ligands with the average Co–N distance 2.158<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Two bridging carboxylate groups, and a water molecular link two different Co centers to form a binuclear Co unit. Adjacent binuclear Co units are connected by NA ligands with nitrogen atom and carboxylate group, respectively, to form a one-dimensional chain along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>a. Such one-dimensional chains are extended to form a two-dimensional layer by pillared NA moleculars along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis as shown in b. The two-dimensional layers are further connected to form a three-dimensional network with bridging NA ligands along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The single crystallographic analysis reveals that complex 2 also exhibits an interesting three-dimensional network. The fundamental unit is shown in b. There are two crystallographically unique Co centers in the asymmetric unit. The NA ligand adopts two kinds of coordination modes as shown in b. The Co(1) center is defined by two nitrogen atoms of two NA ligands with distance Co(1)-N(1)=2.154Å Co(2)-N(2)=2.129Å, two oxygen atoms (Co(1)-O(4)=2.125Å, Co(1)-O(7)=2.035Å) from two bridging carboxylate groups of another two NA ligands, one oxygen atom (Co(1)-O(6)=2.076Å) from a monodentate carboxylate group. Another coordination site is occupied by a water molecular with Co(1)-O(9)=2.170Å. The O-Co(2)-O bond angles are in the range of 83.96°-175.66°. The Co (2) center also adopts distorted octahedral coordination mode, and connected with three oxygen atoms from three carboxylate groups of the NA ligands, two of them with bridging coordination mode, and another adopts monodentate coordination mode with O-Co (2)-O bond angle in the range of 83.79°-178.01° and bond distance range from 2.044 to 2.155Å, one oxygen atom from water molecular, and two nitrogen atoms form NA ligands with the average Co-N distance 2.158Å. Two bridging carboxylate groups, and a water molecular link two different Co centers to form a binuclear Co unit. Adjacent binuclear Co units are connected by NA ligands with nitrogen atom and carboxylate group, respectively, to form a one-dimensional chain along c-axis as shown in  a. Such one-dimensional chains are extended to form a two-dimensional layer by pillared NA moleculars along a-axis as shown in b. The two-dimensional layers are further connected to form a three-dimensional network with bridging NA ligands along b-axis.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Which interested us is along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis; the tetranuclear Co cluster surrounded together formed a honeycomb-like six-numbered ring as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>b. As we all know, the assembly of a honeycomb-like structure is challenging since the hexagon represents the most common patten in nature and is familiar from benzene to the honeycomb of bee. This kind of structure has been previously obtained from the assembly of rigid symmetrical ligand (such as 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid) and transition metal ions. It is uncommon to generate honeycomb-like networks using the NA ligands with relatively low symmetry.</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
IR spectroscopy

The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows characteristic bands of carboxyl group at 1557cm-1 for the anti symmetric stretching and 1405cm-1 for symmetric stretching. The separation (Δ) between γ asym (CO2) and γ sym (CO2) indicates the presence of bridging coordination mode in complex 1. The IR spectrum of complex 2 shows a strong, broad peak at 3315cm-1, which can be ascribed to the presence of water molecules. Characteristic carboxylate group bands appear at 1591cm-1, 1543cm-1, and 1411cm-1 for asymmetric and symmetric vibrations, respectively, the Δ reflecting the coordination modes of the carboxylate group, is 180 and 132cm-1 .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermo gravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The TG curve of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits three weight loss stages. The first weight loss of 4.67% from 80 to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds to the loss of the free water molecule (calcd.:4.54%). The second weight loss 9.18% from 200 to 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is equivalent to the loss of the two coordinated water moleculars (calcd.:9.09%). The third weight loss of 56.48% from 360 to 480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is consistent with removal of the coordinated organic ligands (calcd.:56.56%). For complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 2.96% from 167 to 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is equivalent to the loss of coordinated water (calcd.:2.88%). The second weight loss of 78.09% from 400 to 480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds to the loss of NA ligand (calcd.:78.17%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermo gravimetric analysis

The TG curve of complex 1 exhibits three weight loss stages. The first weight loss of 4.67% from 80 to 120°C corresponds to the loss of the free water molecule (calcd.:4.54%). The second weight loss 9.18% from 200 to 280°C is equivalent to the loss of the two coordinated water moleculars (calcd.:9.09%). The third weight loss of 56.48% from 360 to 480°C is consistent with removal of the coordinated organic ligands (calcd.:56.56%). For complex 2, the weight loss of 2.96% from 167 to 180°C is equivalent to the loss of coordinated water (calcd.:2.88%). The second weight loss of 78.09% from 400 to 480°C corresponds to the loss of NA ligand (calcd.:78.17%).

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In this paper, we successfully combined the merits of Co (II) ions and BTC, NA, and synthesized two new three-dimensional coordination polymers containing hexagon cavities. Furthermore, the two complexes are both composed by tetranuclear Co units. The successful synthesis of the new complexes has demonstrated the ability of unsymmetrical aromatic polycarboxylate ligands to assemble novel higher-dimensional network. The judicious combination of the metal atoms and unsymmetrical ligands will extremely enrich the chemistry of metal-based coordination polymer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this paper, we successfully combined the merits of Co (II) ions and BTC, NA, and synthesized two new three-dimensional coordination polymers containing hexagon cavities. Furthermore, the two complexes are both composed by tetranuclear Co units. The successful synthesis of the new complexes has demonstrated the ability of unsymmetrical aromatic polycarboxylate ligands to assemble novel higher-dimensional network. The judicious combination of the metal atoms and unsymmetrical ligands will extremely enrich the chemistry of metal-based coordination polymer.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

{[Co2(BTC)(OH)(H2O)2]2 ⋅2H2O}n (1)

The best crystals of complex 1 were prepared from a reaction mixture of Co (OAc)2 ⋅2H2O (0.08g), 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate (0.08g) in 6ml of water. The starting mixture was adjusted to pH 7 by the addition of 1M NaOH under vigorous stirring. The final solution was transferred into a 23mL Teflon-lined autoclave and crystallized at 160°C for 4 days. After slowly cooling at 10°C/h to room temperature, the red block crystals were collected by filtration and air-dried (yield: 47% based on Co). Anal. Calcd. For complex 1: C, 27.29% H, 2.53% Co, 29.78% Found: C, 27.60% H, 2.81% N, 29.62%. Selected FTIR data (cm-1): 3659(m), 3592(m), 3384(m), 1617(s), 1557(s), 1497(s), 1431(s), 1405(s), 1259(v), 1181(v), 1079(v), 865(v), 823(s), 777(m), 724(m), 673(m), 631(v), 520(m).

{Co2(NA)4(H2O)}n (2)

The best crystals of complex 2 were prepared from a reaction mixture of Co (OAc)2 ⋅2H2O (0.10g), NA (0.12g 0.50 mmol) and 6ml H2O, stirred for 30min, and then the pH value was adjusted to 6 with 1M NaOH. After stirring for another 30min, the mixture was transferred to a 23ml Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb and kept at 160°C under autogenous pressure for 4 days. The reaction system was cooled to room temperature during 24h. A large amount of red block crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 54% (base on Co). Anal. Calcd. for complex 2: C, 46.13% H, 2.96% N, 8.89% Co, 17.75%. Found: C, 46.30% H, 2.81% N, 8.62% Co, 17.79%. IR: 3315(m), 1616(w), 1591(s), 1543(s), 1476(w), 1447(w), 1411(s), 1311(w), 1284(w), 1159(w), 1113(w), 1006(w), 1000(w), 989(w), 957(w), 858(w), 843(w), 755(m), 712(m), 680(w), 607(w), 541 (w).

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermo gravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The TG curve of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits three weight loss stages. The first weight loss of 4.67% from 80 to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds to the loss of the free water molecule (calcd.:4.54%). The second weight loss 9.18% from 200 to 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is equivalent to the loss of the two coordinated water moleculars (calcd.:9.09%). The third weight loss of 56.48% from 360 to 480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is consistent with removal of the coordinated organic ligands (calcd.:56.56%). For complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 2.96% from 167 to 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is equivalent to the loss of coordinated water (calcd.:2.88%). The second weight loss of 78.09% from 400 to 480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponds to the loss of NA ligand (calcd.:78.17%).</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermo gravimetric analysis

The TG curve of complex 1 exhibits three weight loss stages. The first weight loss of 4.67% from 80 to 120°C corresponds to the loss of the free water molecule (calcd.:4.54%). The second weight loss 9.18% from 200 to 280°C is equivalent to the loss of the two coordinated water moleculars (calcd.:9.09%). The third weight loss of 56.48% from 360 to 480°C is consistent with removal of the coordinated organic ligands (calcd.:56.56%). For complex 2, the weight loss of 2.96% from 167 to 180°C is equivalent to the loss of coordinated water (calcd.:2.88%). The second weight loss of 78.09% from 400 to 480°C corresponds to the loss of NA ligand (calcd.:78.17%).

decomposition temperature.type: loss of two coordinated water molecules
